items.author: Hal Hinson
items.content: A gigantic achievement, an endowment of riches.

items.author: Roger Ebert
items.content: This movie moves so confidently and looks so good it seems incredible that it's a directorial debut.

Costner's directing style is fresh and assured. A sense of surprise and humor accompany Dunbar's adventures at every turn, twisting the narrative gently this way and that and making the journey a real pleasure.

items.author: Desson Thomson
items.content: Costner (with Michael Blake's screenplay) creates a vision so childlike, so willfully romantic, it's hard to put up a fight.

items.author: Gene Siskel
items.content: A three-hour delight The movie generates much of its power by being so life-affirming at a time when people feel nervous about the future. [9 Nov 1990, Friday, p.C]

items.author: Marjorie Baumgarten
items.content: The film's politically correct repudiation of the familiar black-and-white characterizations of the white and red man is ultimately undermined, however, when the pendulum swings too far in the other direction.

items.author: Mick LaSalle
items.content: The picture moves slowly but never sluggishly, and it never grinds down. The measured pace shows real assurance on the part of Costner. [9 Nov 1990, Daily Datebook, p.E1]

items.author: Richard Schickel
items.content: It would be nice, for instance, to meet some white man, other than Dunbar [Costner], who is not a brutish lout. And it would not harm the film if there were one or two bad-natured Sioux visible in it. [12 Nov 1990, p.102]

items.author: David Sterritt
items.content: Smoothly directed by Kevin Costner, who also gives a sensitive performance in the leading role. The screenplay is often trite, however, and there's no reason for the picture's three-hour length. [9 Nov 1990, Arts, p.12]

items.author: Owen Gleiberman
items.content: The movie is so busy turning the Sioux characters into photogenic saints that it never quite allows them the complications of human beings.
